List of cover versions of Black Sabbath songs

The list of cover versions of Black Sabbath songs catalogs the reinterpretations of compositions by Black Sabbath, the Birmingham-based band credited with founding heavy metal through their dark, riff-driven sound pioneered in the late 1960s and early 1970s. Over 98 of the band's original songs have been covered by other artists, spanning heavy metal, hard rock, alternative, and even hip-hop styles, which empirically demonstrates Sabbath's causal role in shaping subsequent musical innovations and their enduring appeal to performers seeking to homage or adapt the genre's primal elements.[1] Prominent examples include Faith No More's funk-infused take on "War Pigs," which highlights the adaptability of Sabbath's anti-war themes and heavy grooves, and Pantera's atmospheric reinterpretation of "Planet Caravan," blending psychedelic space rock with groove metal aggression.[2] Tribute compilations such as Nativity in Black (1994), featuring contributions from acts like Megadeth on "Paranoid" and White Zombie on "Children of the Grave," further underscore the reverence for Sabbath's catalog among metal contemporaries, compiling studio recordings that preserve the originals' occult-tinged intensity while introducing modern production and stylistic variances.[3] These covers, often emphasizing iconic tracks like "Iron Man" and "Paranoid," reveal how Sabbath's minimalist yet powerful song structuresâ€”rooted in Tony Iommi's detuned guitar riffs and Ozzy Osbourne's haunting vocalsâ€”facilitate both loyal tributes and experimental evolutions, without diluting the source material's raw, foundational heaviness.[4]

Cover Versions Organized by Original Song Title

A National Acrobat

"A National Acrobat" has been covered by multiple artists, primarily within heavy metal and related genres, as documented in specialized music databases.[5] The most prominent cover is by Metallica, who incorporated sections of the song into a medley titled "Sabbra Cadabra" (combining it with the preceding track from Sabbath Bloody Sabbath) on their 1998 compilation album Garage Inc.[5] Other recorded versions include:
  • Land of the Blind (1997)[5]
  • Cromwell (1998)[5]
  • Northwinds (1998)[5]
  • Overcast (1998)[5]
  • Co-Exist (July 4, 2005)[5]
  • Fierce Atmospheres (June 5, 2012)[5]
  • A Sound of Thunder (2016)[5]
  • Lotte Kestner (October 12, 2017)[5]
  • Famous Coffee (August 31, 2019; live recording)[5]
  • Summoner (October 30, 2020)[5]
These covers vary in style, from faithful metal renditions to more experimental interpretations, though detailed production notes are limited in available records.[5]

After Forever

"After Forever", a track from Black Sabbath's 1971 album Master of Reality noted for its explicit Christian lyrical themes penned by bassist Geezer Butler, has inspired covers primarily within heavy metal, Christian metal, and hardcore scenes. Notable covers include:
  • Biohazard released a hardcore-infused version on the tribute album Nativity in Black: Tribute to Black Sabbath in 1994, featuring aggressive vocals and rap-metal elements that diverge from the original's acoustic opening.[6]
  • Deliverance, a Christian thrash metal band, covered it in 1991 on their album Stay of Execution, emphasizing the song's faith-based message with high-speed riffing and melodic choruses.[7]
  • Stryper, another Christian metal act, included a faithful yet polished rendition on their 2015 album Fallen, highlighting the track's spiritual content with their signature glam-metal production.[8][9]
  • Zakk Sabbath, Zakk Wylde's Black Sabbath tribute project, delivered a doom-laden take on their 2024 double album Doomed Forever Forever Doomed, which reinterprets tracks from Master of Reality with Wylde's signature guitar tone and piano accents.[10][11]
Additional covers exist by lesser-known acts such as Berserkr (1994), Aurora Borealis (2000), Frost Like Ashes (2003), and Fierce Atmospheres (2012), often appearing on independent releases or compilations within niche metal subgenres.[12]

Behind the Wall of Sleep

Macabre, a deathgrind band from Illinois, released a cover of "Behind the Wall of Sleep" as the title track on their 1994 EP Behind the Wall of Sleep, issued by Nuclear Blast Records on July 25, 1994.[13][14] Eyehategod incorporated the song into their sludge metal medley "Sabbath Jam" (combining elements of Black Sabbath's "Cornucopia," "Hand of Doom," and "Behind the Wall of Sleep") on the 1997 tribute compilation In These Black Days: A Tribute to Black Sabbath, Vol. 1, released by Earache Records.[15][16] Static-X delivered an industrial metal rendition on the 2000 tribute album Nativity in Black II: A Tribute to Black Sabbath, where it served as the third track.[17][18] Felonious Bosch, an obscure metal act, covered the track in 2006.[19] Greek stoner rock band Planet of Zeus recorded a Southern rock-inflected version in 2013.[19] Zakk Sabbath, the Black Sabbath tribute project led by guitarist Zakk Wylde, included it in the 2020 medley "Wasp â€“ Behind the Wall of Sleep â€“ N.I.B." on their album Vertigo.[19][20] Jazz Sabbath, featuring jazz interpretations of Black Sabbath material by Adam Rogers (guitar), Antonio Sanchez (drums), and Dave Liebman (saxophone), released an instrumental cover in 2022.[19] Additional adaptations include a Latin-language version titled "Post murum somnii" by Rondellus in 2002 and a 2017 cover by Brazilian doom/sludge band Jupiterian.[21][19]

Black Sabbath

The song "Black Sabbath", written by Geezer Butler, Tony Iommi, Ozzy Osbourne, and Bill Ward, serves as the opening track and title song of the band's eponymous debut album released on February 13, 1970.[22] Its ominous riff and horror-themed lyrics have inspired covers primarily within metal and alternative genres, frequently appearing on tribute compilations that reinterpret the original's doom-laden atmosphere.
ArtistRelease TitleYearNotes
Type O NegativeNativity in Black: A Tribute to Black Sabbath1994Retitled "Black Sabbath (From the Satanic Perspective)"; gothic metal rendition with slowed tempo and altered lyrics from a satanic viewpoint; also reissued on the band's October Rust album in 1996.[23][24]
Zakk SabbathVertigo Machine2020Instrumental-heavy cover band led by Zakk Wylde recreates the full debut album track-for-track; emphasizes raw guitar tone faithful to the original.[25][26]
The Soft MoonWhat Is This That Stands Before Me?2020Post-punk/industrial reinterpretation on Sacred Bones Records tribute; features distorted electronics and pitched-up elements for a darker, atmospheric vibe.[27][28]
These covers highlight the song's enduring influence on heavy music subgenres, with tributes often amplifying its supernatural themes through stylistic experimentation.[29]

Changes

"Changes", a piano-driven ballad from Black Sabbath's 1972 album Vol. 4, has inspired covers across genres including country, soul, punk, and metal, with over 45 documented versions by other artists as of 2025.[30]

Children of the Grave

White Zombie recorded a cover of "Children of the Grave" for the 1994 tribute album Nativity in Black: A Tribute to Black Sabbath, featuring altered lyrics and a promotional single release later that year. The version incorporates the band's industrial metal style, emphasizing heavier grooves and electronic elements compared to the original from Black Sabbath's 1971 album Master of Reality.[36] Lamb of God released a studio cover on July 5, 2025, via Epic Records, following their live performance at the "Back to the Beginning" tribute concert honoring Ozzy Osbourne and Black Sabbath on July 4, 2025.[37] [38] The rendition retains the song's aggressive riffing while infusing groove metal intensity, with vocalist Randy Blythe delivering a raw interpretation.[39] Amon Amarth included a cover on their 2011 live EP Hymns to the Rising Sun, adapting the track with melodic death metal elements and Viking-themed vocal stylings.[40] This version highlights the band's rhythmic drive and choral-like backing, diverging from the original's doom-laden pace.[41]
ArtistYearReleaseNotes
White Zombie1994Nativity in BlackIndustrial metal adaptation; promo single.
Amon Amarth2011Hymns to the Rising Sun (live)Melodic death metal style.
Lamb of God2025Single (Epic Records)Groove metal; post-tribute concert release.

Children of the Sea

"Children of the Sea", the second track from Black Sabbath's 1980 album Heaven and Hell, features lyrics by Ronnie James Dio and has inspired covers primarily within heavy and power metal genres.[42] Sleepy Hollow recorded a version for their self-titled debut album, released in 1991 on Magna Carta Records, preserving the original's epic structure with added doom influences characteristic of the band's style.[43][44] Jag Panzer contributed a faithful rendition to the tribute compilation Evil Lives: A True Metal Tribute to Black Sabbath, issued in 2004 by Magick Records, emphasizing the song's soaring melodies and Dio-era Sabbath dynamics.[45][46] Silver Fist, a Spanish heavy metal band, featured their interpretation on the double album Ave FÃ©nix in 2004 via Avispa Records, integrating it among covers of other classic metal tracks while maintaining a speed metal edge.[47][48] King Witch released a doom-laden cover on their digital EP Worship the Riffs in 2021, recorded during lockdown and highlighting the track's atmospheric qualities with female vocals diverging from the original's baritone delivery.[49][50]

Cornucopia

  • Brutal Truth covered "Cornucopia" on the Black Sabbath tribute split 7" In These Black Days Volume 2 with Converge, released in 1997 and recorded in New York City at Baby Monster Studios.[51][52]
  • Eyehategod included a medley version titled "Sabbath Jam" (incorporating "Cornucopia", "Hand of Doom", and "Behind the Wall of Sleep") on their album Take as Needed for Pain, released July 29, 1996.[52]
  • Infamy performed the song on the tribute album Hell Rules: A Tribute to Black Sabbath, released May 11, 1999.[52][53]
  • Overkill released a cover on their covers album Coverkill, issued October 26, 1999.[52]
  • Iron Monkey contributed a version to the Black Sabbath tribute Masters of Misery - Black Sabbath: The Earache Tribute, with their track appearing on the 1992 original and subsequent editions.[54]
  • Whores. delivered a doom-laden rendition on the tribute album Vol. 4 [Redux], released October 30, 2020, via Magnetic Eye Records as part of a Black Sabbath anniversary series.[52][55][56]

Die Young

"Die Young", the sixth track on Black Sabbath's 1980 album Heaven and Hell, has been covered primarily by heavy metal bands, often as studio recordings on albums or tributes, with some live versions also documented.[57]

Additional covers include acoustic renditions, such as Machine Head frontman Robb Flynn's 2010 solo acoustic version released as a tribute to Black Sabbath manager Debbie Abono,[63] and Suicide Silence's acoustic live performance featuring Flynn at the 2013 Mitch Lucker Memorial Show.[64] Less prominent covers exist by acts like Mesmerize (2001), Endomain (2017), Emerald Sabbath (2019), and Trial (2021), often on independent or tribute releases.[57]

Dirty Women

"Dirty Women", the eighth track from Black Sabbath's 1976 album Technical Ecstasy, has been covered by a limited number of artists, primarily within the rock and stoner genres.[65] The Swedish garage rock band The Hellacopters released a cover in 1998, featured as the A-side of their 7-inch single Dirty Women b/w I Only Got the Shakes and later included on the 2000 compilation Cream of the Crap! Vol. 2.[66][67] American stoner rock band Mos Generator contributed a version to the 2015 tribute album Sweet Leaf: A Stoner Rock Salute to Black Sabbath, released on October 30, 2015.[68][69] American rock band Spillage included a cover featuring guest guitarist Bruce Franklin (ex-UFO, Blue Murder) as a bonus track on their 2019 album Blood of Angels.[70]

Disturbing the Priest

"Disturbing the Priest", originally from Black Sabbath's 1983 album Born Again, has been covered by various metal bands, often preserving the song's dark, atmospheric heavy metal style while incorporating genre-specific elements like death metal growls or progressive twists.[71] Coffin Texts included a cover on the 1999 tribute compilation Hell Rules: A Tribute to Black Sabbath.[72] The band later re-recorded it for their 2000 album Gods of Creation, Death & Afterlife, emphasizing brutal death metal riffs and vocals.[73] Psychotic Waltz recorded a studio version as a bonus track on the 2013 reissue of their album Into the Everflow, featuring progressive metal instrumentation that extends the runtime to over six minutes.[74] Soilent Green incorporated the song into a medley titled "Lord of the Southern Priest" on their 1999 album A Deleted Symphony for the Insane, blending it with other tracks in a sludge metal style.[75] Order of Nine covered it in 2004, delivering a straightforward heavy metal rendition faithful to the original's structure.[75] Swedish heavy metal band RAM featured a cover on their 2003 debut EP Sudden Impact, characterized by raw, high-energy production typical of traditional metal revival acts.[76]

Electric Funeral

"Electric Funeral", originally released by Black Sabbath on their 1970 album Paranoid, has inspired at least 31 documented cover versions across metal, rock, and instrumental genres, spanning from 1986 to 2024.[77] These covers often appear on tribute albums, medleys, or standalone releases, preserving the song's heavy riffing and apocalyptic themes while adapting it to various styles such as doom metal, thrash, and string quartet arrangements. The following table lists selected verified studio and notable live covers, excluding unverified or highly altered renditions:

Additional live performances include Rival Sons at the 2025 "Back to the Beginning" event honoring Black Sabbath.[80] Covers frequently emphasize the song's environmental critique, with some artists like Solace extending its sludge-heavy interpretation.[81]

Fairies Wear Boots

"Fairies Wear Boots" has inspired numerous covers, ranging from studio recordings to high-profile live renditions, often by heavy metal and tribute acts preserving its psychedelic heavy riff structure and lyrical themes of hallucinatory experiences.[82] The Necro Tonz released a studio version titled "Faeries Wear Boots" in 2002 as part of their hip-hop metal fusion style.[83] Hand of Doom, a Sabbath tribute project, recorded a cover released on October 22, 2002, emphasizing the original's doom-laden tempo.[83] Zakk Sabbath, Zakk Wylde's Black Sabbath tribute band, has performed and released versions, including on their 2020 instrumental album Vertigo, maintaining instrumental fidelity to the 1970 original while adding shred guitar flourishes.[84] Mirthkon included a cover on their recordings, blending it with progressive elements.[85] Live covers gained prominence at tribute events; Alice in Chains delivered a rendition on July 5, 2025, at the "Back to the Beginning" festival in Birmingham, England, with William DuVall's vocals channeling Ozzy Osbourne's style amid the grunge band's sludge tone.[86] Brownout, performing as Brown Sabbath, offered a funk-infused Latin reinterpretation live on KEXP radio on January 18, 2017.[87] Blackberry Smoke played it live at Cabaret Sauvage in Paris on an unspecified date in 2018, infusing Southern rock energy.[88] Phil X & The Drills released a hard rock cover on May 18, 2020, featuring Bon Jovi guitarist Phil X's precise riffing.[89] Jazz Sabbath, a jazz metal ensemble, adapted it with improvisational saxophone leads in their repertoire.[90] L.A. Guns performed a web-exclusive version on April 21, 2014, in their glam metal vein.[91]

Hand of Doom

"Hand of Doom" has been covered by various artists, primarily within heavy metal, doom, and sludge genres, often preserving the original's heavy riffing and themes of heroin addiction.[92] Recorded versions span from the early 1990s onward, with some appearing on tribute albums or as medleys.[92]

Heaven and Hell

"Heaven and Hell", the title track from Black Sabbath's 1980 album featuring vocalist Ronnie James Dio, has been covered by various heavy metal and related acts, often preserving its epic structure while adapting it to different styles.[94] Notable studio versions include Solitude Aeturnus on their 1998 album Adagio, emphasizing doom metal elements with slower tempos and atmospheric production.[95][94]

Live covers include performances by Dream Theater in 2009 and Dio himself in 1998, reflecting the song's enduring appeal in concert settings.[94] Additional renditions appear on tribute compilations, such as Molchat Doma's post-punk version on the 2020 Sacred Bones Records release What Is This That Stands Before Me?.[96] These covers typically retain the song's dual-part structure, with the first half's acoustic intro building to the heavier electric riff section, though some artists accelerate the pace or add orchestral elements.[94]

Hole in the Sky

"Hole in the Sky," the opening track from Black Sabbath's 1975 album Sabotage, has inspired covers primarily within heavy metal and related genres, often emphasizing its aggressive riffing and lyrical themes of disillusionment.[97] Notable studio covers include those by Machine Head in 2000, featured on the tribute album Nativity in Black II: A Tribute to Black Sabbath, which retains the original's intensity while incorporating the band's groove metal style.[98] Pantera recorded a version in 2003, delivering a thrash-infused rendition that highlights the song's Sabbath-era edge.[97] [99] Other recorded versions encompass a range of interpretations, as documented in cover databases:

I

Faroese viking/folk metal band TÃ½r recorded a cover of "I" as a bonus track on their fifth studio album The Lay of Thrym, released on May 27, 2011, by Metal Blade Records. The version retains the original's aggressive riffing while incorporating TÃ½r's characteristic melodic folk elements and clean vocals. Brazilian thrash metal band Ancesttral included a cover of "I" on their 2012 EP Bloodshed and Violence, self-released as a digital album.[102] Clocking in at approximately 5:54, the rendition emphasizes high-speed thrash delivery and raw production, aligning with the band's style on the release which also features covers of other Sabbath tracks like "Sabbra Cadabra."[102]

Into the Void

Kyuss recorded an eight-minute version of "Into the Void" for their 1996 single Into the Void / Fatso Forgetso, emphasizing the song's heavy riff in a stoner rock style.[103] Monster Magnet contributed a cover to the 2000 tribute album Nativity in Black II: A Tribute to Black Sabbath, preserving the original's psychedelic edge while adding space rock elements.[104] Soundgarden's adaptation, titled "Into the Void (Sealth)", was released in 1991 on the rarities compilation Satanoscillatorometallicsonatas (later reissued on Echo of Miles: Scattered Tracks Across the Path in 2014); it retains the instrumental structure but replaces the lyrics with excerpts from a speech attributed to Chief Seattle.[105] Cancer Bats delivered a punk-infused rendition in 2013, available as a standalone track.[106] Additional covers include those by Exhorder, featured in heavy metal compilations, and instrumental interpretations by groups like the Vitamin String Quartet.[104] The song has also been performed live by acts such as Anthrax in 2025 at tribute events and Zakk Sabbath in early 2025 concerts, highlighting its enduring appeal in metal circles.[107][108] These versions often amplify the track's doom-laden atmosphere, originally from Black Sabbath's 1971 album Master of Reality.[109]

Iron Man

"Iron Man", from Black Sabbath's 1970 album Paranoid, has been adapted by artists spanning hip-hop, alternative rock, punk, and metal, often retaining its heavy riff while altering vocals or instrumentation for stylistic contrast.[110] Studio covers frequently appear on tribute compilations or original albums, with notable examples emphasizing genre fusion, such as rap-metal hybrids or acoustic reinterpretations.[110] The song's enduring appeal is evident in its sampling and covering frequency, documented in music databases tracking over 30 studio versions since the 1980s.[110] Live renditions by acts like Metallica, sometimes joined by Ozzy Osbourne, have also popularized it at festivals and tribute events.[111]

It's Alright

"It's Alright" is the third track on Black Sabbath's sixth studio album, Technical Ecstasy, released on September 25, 1976.[118] Written primarily by drummer Bill Ward, the song features a bluesy, mid-tempo structure atypical of the band's heavier output, with Ward providing lead vocals alongside Ronnie James Dio-era influences absent from the original recording.[118] The track has inspired a limited number of covers, mostly within niche metal subgenres and live performances by prominent acts, reflecting its relative obscurity compared to Sabbath staples like "Paranoid" or "Iron Man."
ArtistYearRelease/DetailsCitation
Guns N' Roses1992Live performance in Houston, Texas; also performed in Paris on June 6, 1992, medley with "November Rain"[119]

These covers underscore the song's appeal to extreme and hard rock acts, though none achieved mainstream commercial release or chart success. Guns N' Roses' interpretations, leveraging Axl Rose's vocal range, stand out for visibility due to the band's stature, often performed as tributes during Sabbath-related events.[126] Underground efforts like those by 7000 Dying Rats and Anal Cunt adapt the original's groove into grindcore and noise frameworks, preserving its riff-driven essence amid distortion.[125]

Jerusalem

"Jerusalem", the third track from Black Sabbath's 1990 album Tyr, has been covered sparingly, with notable versions by former Black Sabbath vocalist Tony Martin and the Greek metal band Nightfall.[127]

Killing Yourself to Live

Anal Cunt, a grindcore band, recorded a studio cover released on the 2000 tribute album Masters of Misery: The Earache Tribute to Black Sabbath.[132] Sorrows Path, a Greek heavy metal band, included a studio version on the 2013 compilation Sabbath Cadabra: A Greek Tribute to Black Sabbath.[133] [134] Other recorded covers include Ted Maul's studio rendition from August 25, 2010,[135] and Mantasuka's studio version from June 5, 2012.[136] These versions, tracked by cover song databases, reflect the song's influence in underground metal scenes, though they remain lesser-known compared to covers of Black Sabbath's more mainstream tracks.[137]

Letters from Earth

Norwegian heavy metal vocalist JÃ¸rn Lande recorded a medley combining "Letters from Earth" with the preceding track "Lonely Is the Word" from the same Black Sabbath album Dehumanizer. The cover appears as the fourth track on Lande's covers album Unlocking the Past, released January 26, 2007, by AFM Records.[138] [139] This studio rendition credits the composition to Black Sabbath members Tony Iommi, Geezer Butler, and Ronnie James Dio, preserving the original's atmospheric heavy metal style while showcasing Lande's Dio-influenced vocal delivery.[140] The medley was later reissued on Lande's 2010 Dio tribute album Dio, further emphasizing its homage to Dio-era Black Sabbath material.[141] No other studio covers of "Letters from Earth" have been widely documented in discographies.[142]

Lord of This World

"Lord of This World" has been covered by at least a dozen artists since its original release on Black Sabbath's 1971 album Master of Reality, often by bands in the doom, sludge, and heavy metal genres that draw from Sabbath's pioneering sound.[143] Notable studio covers include Brutal Truth's rendition in 1992, which appears on their EP Brutal Truth.[143] Sleep recorded a version the same year, featured on their album Sleep's Holy Mountain.[143] Helmet released their take in August 1994.[143] Corrosion of Conformity contributed a gritty interpretation in 1994 for the tribute album Nativity in Black: A Tribute to Black Sabbath.[143] Soilent Green incorporated it into a medley titled "Lord of the Southern Priest" in 1999 on their album A Deleted Symphony for the Insane.[143] Later covers encompass Vile's in March 2000, QuixoTic's on July 9, 2002, and Thou's heavy reworking on May 12, 2009, as part of their split album A Primer of Holy Words.[143] One Inch Giant included it in a medley on June 5, 2012.[143] A collaborative version by Trevor McNevan, Bruce Franklin, Dug Pinnick, and Ted Kirkpatrick was released on January 20, 2016.[143] Howling Giant covered it on October 30, 2020, for the tribute compilation Best of Black Sabbath.[143] [144] Most recently, Zakk Sabbath delivered a faithful rendition on March 1, 2024.[143]

Megalomania

Venom, an English heavy metal band, recorded a studio cover of "Megalomania" for their sixth album Prime Evil, released on April 10, 1989, by Enigma Records.[145] This version amplifies the original's aggressive riffs with Venom's thrash metal edge, featuring faster tempos and rawer vocals while preserving the song's core structure from Black Sabbath's 1975 Sabotage release.[145][146]

The Mob Rules

"The Mob Rules", originally released by Black Sabbath on their 1981 album of the same name, has been covered by various heavy metal acts, often as tributes to the Dio-era lineup.[147] Fozzy recorded a version for their third studio album Happenstance, released on July 18, 2006, via Megaforce Records, preserving the high-energy riffing and vocal intensity of the original.[148][149] Benedictum included a faithful rendition on their debut album Uncreation, issued in 2006 by Crash Music, with the track clocking in at 3:14 and featuring the band's emphasis on classic metal influences.[150][151] Adrenaline Mob released a cover on their 2013 EP CovertÃ , distributed via Entertainment One Music, which captured the song's aggressive drive in a modern supergroup context led by vocalist Russell Allen and drummer Mike Portnoy. Other interpretations include live and session performances, such as Myles Kennedy's acoustic rendition for SiriusXM's Planet Rock in May 2021, highlighting the song's melodic structure in a stripped-down format, though not formally released as a studio track.[152]

Neon Knights

"Neon Knights", the opening track from Black Sabbath's 1980 album Heaven and Hell, has been covered by numerous heavy metal acts, often as tributes to the song's co-writer Ronnie James Dio or in homage to Sabbath's influence.[153] These versions typically retain the song's aggressive riffing and occult-themed lyrics while adapting to the covering artists' styles, ranging from power metal to death metal interpretations.[153]

Never Say Die!

"Never Say Die!" was covered by the thrash metal band Overkill on their covers album Coverkill, released on October 26, 1999.[159][160] Megadeth included a version on the Black Sabbath tribute album Nativity in Black II, released in 2000.[161] The Leaving Trains recorded a cover in 2001.[161] Imagika released their rendition in 2002.[161] Holy Mother featured the song on an album issued July 21, 2003.[161] Baltimoore covered it in 2003.[161] Electric Frankenstein's version appeared in 2004.[161] Instrumental stoner rock band Karma to Burn included an adaptation on their album V, released in 2011.[162][163] Driving Mrs. Satan produced an acoustic cover in 2013.[164][165] The BellRays recorded a version released April 22, 2016.[161] Earthless contributed a cover to the tribute compilation Best of Black Sabbath, released October 30, 2020.[161][166] Mark Bodino released a solo cover on March 28, 2025.[161] Additionally, Guns N' Roses performed the song live during their concert in Birmingham on July 5, 2025.[167]

N.I.B.

"N.I.B.", originally released by Black Sabbath on their self-titled debut album in 1970, has inspired numerous covers by heavy metal, punk, and alternative acts, frequently on tribute compilations or standalone releases.[168] Prominent examples include versions on the 1994 tribute album Nativity in Black: A Tribute to Black Sabbath, such as Primus featuring Ozzy Osbourne on vocals for a studio rendition emphasizing the song's bass-driven riff and thematic lyrics about infernal temptation.[169] Ugly Kid Joe delivered a high-energy take on the same album, blending Sabbath's doom elements with their grunge-metal style.[170] Other studio covers encompass Pitchshifter's industrial metal adaptation in 1992, Cancer Bats' punk-infused version in 2013, Danzig's gothic reinterpretation in 2015, and Krokus' hard rock revival in 2017.[168] Zakk Sabbath, a Black Sabbath tribute project led by Zakk Wylde, incorporated "N.I.B." into a medley on their 2020 release Vertigo Machine, preserving the original's ominous bass intro while adding Wylde's signature shredding.[168][171]

Over and Over

Pallbearer, an American doom metal band, released a cover of "Over and Over" on their Fear and Fury EP on August 10, 2016, featuring a slower, atmospheric interpretation emphasizing the song's melancholic elements.[172] The track was also performed live by the band in subsequent concerts.[173] Brathair, a band incorporating doom influences, issued a cover as a single from their debut album on February 20, 2025, featuring guitarist Victor Griffin and bassist Greg Turley, both formerly of Pentagram, providing a heavy, riff-driven take honoring the original's Ronnie James Dio-era Sabbath sound.[174] Rock 'n' Roll Children, a Greek tribute band to Ronnie James Dio, performed a live version in May 2017, often medleyed with other Sabbath tracks, though no official studio release exists.[175][176]

Paranoid

"Paranoid" has been covered extensively by artists spanning punk, heavy metal, and industrial genres, reflecting its enduring appeal as a high-energy anthem with a memorable guitar riff. Over 90 recorded versions exist, many appearing on tribute albums or as stylistic reinterpretations.[177][178] Notable studio covers include:
  • The Dickies' fast-paced punk rendition, released in 1979 on their debut album The Incredible Shrinking Dickies, which charted at No. 45 in the UK.[179]
  • Type O Negative's doom-laden, slowed-down version as a bonus track on their 1992 live album The Origin of the Feces, emphasizing melancholic vocals and heavy atmosphere.[180]
  • Megadeth's thrash metal take, originally featured on the 1994 Black Sabbath tribute album Nativity in Black: A Tribute to Black Sabbath and later reissued on their 1995 EP Hidden Treasures.[181]
  • Avenged Sevenfold's aggressive metal cover, initially released as a single in 2003 and included on their 2008 compilation Diamonds in the Rough.[182]
  • Ministry's industrial rework on their 2010 covers album Undercover, incorporating electronic elements and distorted production.[183]

Planet Caravan

"Planet Caravan", originally released by Black Sabbath on their 1970 album Paranoid, has been covered by over two dozen artists in studio and live formats, spanning rock, psychedelic, and instrumental interpretations.[184] These versions often retain the song's dreamy, psychedelic atmosphere while adapting it to different styles, such as groove metal or ambient drone. Notable studio covers include Pantera's rendition on their 1994 album Far Beyond Driven, which peaked at number 26 on the UK Singles Chart and features a heavier, groove-oriented arrangement.[184] Mercury Rev included a version on their 2002 compilation The Merriest, emphasizing ethereal psychedelia.[184] Zakk Sabbath, led by Zakk Wylde, released a faithful yet dynamic take in 2024 on Doom Crew Inc., preserving the original's spacey vibe with guitar prowess.[184] Other covers encompass underground and niche acts, such as Union Carbide Productions' 1990 raw punk-infused version and Brownout's 2014 Latin-tinged rendition featuring David Longoria.[184] Instrumental adaptations, like Michael Leonhart's 2002 jazz-inflected track, highlight the song's melodic versatility.[184]

Rat Salad

"Rat Salad", the instrumental track from Black Sabbath's 1970 album Paranoid featuring drummer Bill Ward's solo, has been covered by a limited number of artists, primarily in tribute compilations and reinterpretations.[185] Surplus 1980 recorded a version for the tribute album UnderCover Presents Paranoid: A Tribute to Black Sabbath, released on May 19, 2012.[186] Aseethe released a deconstructed, extended 13-minute interpretation as part of the Black Sabbath - Paranoid: The CVLT Nation Sessions project, issued on July 16, 2015.[187] Jazz Sabbath, a jazz-infused tribute act, included a cover on their 2020 release.[188] Zakk Sabbath, featuring Zakk Wylde on guitar, John J. Sabbath Bloody Sabbath

Anthrax covered "Sabbath Bloody Sabbath" on their 1987 EP I'm the Man, infusing the track with thrash metal aggression while retaining the original's riff-driven structure.[191] Bruce Dickinson, in collaboration with the band Godspeed, recorded a version for the 1994 tribute album Nativity in Black: Tribute to Black Sabbath, emphasizing vocal dramatics and heavy orchestration true to the song's epic scope.[192] Today Is the Day included a raw, noise-influenced rendition on their 1996 album Suicide, stripping back elements for an abrasive, experimental edge.[193] Tarot delivered a power metal interpretation on their 2006 album For the Glory of Nothing, accelerating the tempo and adding symphonic layers.[194] Candlemass released a doom-laden cover as part of their 2025 EP Black Star, marking a homage to their influences with brooding tempos and operatic vocals on May 9, 2025.[195] Live performances include Guns N' Roses' rendition during Black Sabbath's "Back to the Beginning" event on August 4, 2025, showcasing Axl Rose's interpretation amid high-energy stage dynamics.[196] Other versions encompass string quartet arrangements by Vitamin String Quartet and collaborations like Al Cisneros with Melvins, highlighting the song's adaptability across genres from metal to experimental.[197]

Sabbra Cadabra

Metallica's cover of "Sabbra Cadabra," recorded as a medley incorporating elements of Black Sabbath's "A National Acrobat," appears on the compilation album Garage Inc., released on November 24, 1998.[198] The band first performed the medley live on November 17, 1998, in Kansas City, Missouri, blending heavy metal riffs with harmonized vocal sections that extend beyond the original structure.[198] (hed) P.E. recorded a nu-metal rendition for their second studio album Broke, released on August 22, 2000, via Jive Records, preserving the song's riff-driven groove while adding rap-rock vocal delivery and heavier production.[199] [200] Jazz Sabbath, an instrumental jazz trio paying homage to Black Sabbath's catalog, released an uptempo, bebop-infused version on their album Vol. 2 on April 22, 2022, through Blacklake Records, emphasizing improvisational saxophone leads over the original's doom-laden tempo.[201] [202] The grindcore band Anal Cunt included "Sabbra Cadabra" in a chaotic medley titled "Itâ€™s Alright - Sabbra Cadabra - Blow on a Jug" on their 1997 album I Like It When You Get Destroyed, sampling elements from the Steve Miller Band's "Abracadabra" for a punk-noise reinterpretation.[203]

The Shining

Ronnie Romero, vocalist for projects including Rainbow and Sun King, covered "The Shining" with guitarist Chris Caffery on November 14, 2022, as the lead single from his hard rock and heavy metal covers album.[204][205] The recording retains the original's heavy riffing and structure from Black Sabbath's 1987 album The Eternal Idol, while Romero's delivery echoes Tony Martin's range.[206] An official music video was released concurrently, showcasing the performance.[207] No other studio covers by established artists have been widely documented.[206]

Snowblind

"Snowblind", the sixth track on Black Sabbath's 1972 album Vol. 4, has been covered extensively by artists in heavy metal, doom, hardcore, and instrumental styles, often emphasizing its raw riffing and thematic intensity.[216] These interpretations range from studio recordings on tribute albums to live performances, with over a dozen documented versions highlighting the song's influence on subsequent generations of musicians.[216][217] System of a Down delivered a frenetic, riff-driven take on the 2000 tribute compilation Nativity in Black II, characterized by Serj Tankian's erratic vocals and the band's signature nu-metal aggression.[218] The group revived the cover live at MetLife Stadium on August 27, 2025, marking their first performance of it in over two decades as a homage to Ozzy Osbourne.[219] Sleep's 1992 version, appearing on the Earache Records tribute Masters of Misery: The Earache Tribute to Black Sabbath, adopts a dronier, orthodox doom approach faithful to Sabbath's sludge roots.[217] Converge contributed a raw, shambolic hardcore rendition in 1997 for the In These Black Days 7-inch tribute series, featuring straight-edge vocalist Jake Bannon's intense delivery.[217][216] Evoken's funeral-doom adaptation from the 2000 compilation Hell Rules 2 incorporates sludge elements, reverb-heavy atmosphere, and an accelerating tempo toward its close.[217][216] Jason Molina's sparse acoustic interpretation, recorded in the 1990s and released posthumously on the Black Sabbath Covers EP, strips the track to voice and guitar for an intimate folk rendering.[217] Other notable studio covers include Black Label Society's live-infused take in 2001, 1000mods' stoner rock version in 2013, Brownout's Latin-infused reinterpretation in 2016, and Jazz Sabbath's swinging instrumental on their 2022 album.[216] Ozzy Osbourne performed it live in 1982 during his solo tour, bridging his Sabbath legacy with post-band material.[216] Green Lung offered a heavy psych update in 2020.[216]

Solitude

"Solitude", a track from Black Sabbath's 1971 album Master of Reality, has inspired covers by artists spanning doom metal, progressive metal, ambient, and classical crossover genres, often emphasizing its melancholic flute and bass-driven melody.[220] Cathedral recorded a studio version in 1992 for the tribute album Nativity in Black: Tribute to Black Sabbath, preserving the original's doom-laden atmosphere with added sludge elements.[220][221] Magnifico Giganticus released a studio cover in 1998, maintaining fidelity to the source material within their stoner rock style.[220] The Vitamin String Quartet produced an instrumental rendition in 2002 on VSQ Performs Black Sabbath, transforming the heavy rock track into a string quartet arrangement that highlights its somber themes.[220] Ulver delivered a studio version in October 2007, infusing experimental black metal influences into the composition.[220] Lassi Valtonen performed a studio take in 2011, adapted for a Finnish TV talent show context.[220] Opeth issued a studio cover in August 2014, though the band is also noted for live acoustic renditions, such as at SÃ¶dra Teatern in Stockholm in 2012 and a tribute performance at Beyond the Gates festival in 2025 honoring Ozzy Osbourne.[220][222][223] Marissa Nadler covered it in studio in April 2016, aligning with her folk and gothic style.[220] Shlomi Kendel released a studio version in January 2018.[220] Brume provided a studio doom metal interpretation in October 2020.[220] Zakk Sabbath, a Black Sabbath tribute project led by Zakk Wylde, recorded a studio cover released on March 1, 2024.[220] More recent entries include Mark Bodino's studio version from March 28, 2025.[220]

Spiral Architect

Finnish cello metal band Apocalyptica released an instrumental cover of "Spiral Architect" on their eighth studio album 7th Symphony, issued on August 20, 2010, via Sony Music; the track reinterprets the original's progressive structure through layered cello arrangements, emphasizing atmospheric dynamics over vocals.[224][225] This version also appeared on a Black Sabbath tribute CD distributed with the March 2010 issue of Metal Hammer magazine.[226] Estonian medieval music ensemble Rondellus produced a choral, Latin-titled adaptation entitled "Architectus Urbis Caelestis" for their album Sabbatum: A Medieval Tribute to Black Sabbath, released in 2003; the rendition transforms the song into a Gregorian chant-inspired piece, stripping heavy metal elements for acoustic vocal harmonies and period instrumentation.[227][228] French progressive rock group Oms en sÃ©rie included a faithful cover of "Spiral Architect" on their 2019 release, maintaining the original's tempo and riffing while incorporating modern production.[229]

St. Vitus Dance

Sweet Leaf

"Sweet Leaf", the opening track from Black Sabbath's 1971 album Master of Reality, has inspired numerous covers by heavy metal, rock, and alternative artists, often retaining its riff-driven structure while adapting to different styles such as sludge, doom, or instrumental arrangements.[244] These versions span from the early 1980s to the 2020s, with many appearing on tribute albums, medleys, or standalone releases.[244] [245] The song's appeal lies in its iconic guitar riff and thematic nod to cannabis, leading to reinterpretations in stoner rock and metal subgenres.[244] Databases like SecondHandSongs document over 30 covers, including both vocal and instrumental takes.[244]

Symptom of the Universe

"Symptom of the Universe", originally released by Black Sabbath on their 1975 album Sabotage, has been covered by numerous artists, primarily within heavy metal and related genres, reflecting its influence on thrash, doom, and sludge substyles.[246] These renditions often emphasize the song's aggressive riffing and proto-thrash structure, with variations ranging from faithful reproductions to experimental reinterpretations. Studio recordings dominate documented covers, though live performances by tribute acts and supergroups have also proliferated, particularly in recent years. Notable covers include Ozzy Osbourne's live version from his 1982 double album Speak of the Devil, which features Sabbath material performed with new bandmates Randy Rhoads and later Brad Gillis.[247] Sepultura delivered a thrash-infused take in 1994 for the tribute compilation Nativity in Black: Tribute to Black Sabbath, accelerating the tempo and incorporating groove elements characteristic of their mid-1990s sound.[235]

The Sign of the Southern Cross

"The Sign of the Southern Cross", the third track from Black Sabbath's 1981 album Mob Rules, has been covered by various heavy metal acts, often in tribute compilations or standalone releases.[251] These versions typically retain the song's epic structure and mystical themes, with adaptations varying in fidelity to the original's instrumentation and vocal delivery. Notable studio covers include Fates Warning's rendition, released on July 12, 1999, as part of the tribute album Holy Dio: A Tribute to the Father of Heavy Metal. Death Omen contributed a cover in 2002 on the compilation Hail to the Stonehenge Gods: A Tribute to Black Sabbath, emphasizing doom-laden riffs.[252][253] Vicious Rumors released their version on November 23, 2012.

The Wizard

"The Wizard", a track from Black Sabbath's 1970 debut album featuring prominent harmonica by Ozzy Osbourne, has inspired covers spanning heavy metal, jazz, and experimental genres, often emphasizing its blues-rock structure.[259] Notable studio covers include:
  • Bullring Brummies (featuring Rob Halford on vocals, Geezer Butler on bass, and Bill Ward on drums) on the 1994 tribute album Nativity in Black: A Tribute to Black Sabbath, delivering a sludge-heavy rendition with Halford's soaring vocals.
  • Pride & Glory (Zakk Wylde's southern rock project) on their 1994 self-titled album, incorporating acoustic elements and Wylde's slide guitar for a rootsy interpretation.
  • Botch on a 1999 compilation, adapting it into a mathcore style with intense breakdowns.
  • Turbowolf on a 2010 release, infusing garage rock energy.
  • Zakk Sabbath (Wylde's Black Sabbath tribute band) on their 2020 album Vertigo, a faithful yet blistering recreation of the debut album's tracks.
  • Jazz Sabbath on their 2024 album The 1968 Tapes, reimagining it as an instrumental jazz fusion piece with Hammond organ and improvisational flair.[260]
Live and other versions include Will Wilde's 2018 harmonica-led cover highlighting the song's blues origins, and Bonerama's 2004 brass band adaptation. Additional covers by acts like Scorn (1992 industrial dub), Trinitone (1998), and Brownout (2014 Latin funk-jazz) demonstrate the song's versatility across subgenres.[259]

Time Machine

Pegazus, an Australian heavy metal band, included a cover of "Time Machine" as a bonus track on their album Breaking the Chains, released on September 10, 2008.[261][262] Circle of Silence performed a version on the tribute compilation A Light in the Black: A Tribute to Ronnie James Dio, released in 2015, where it appears as track 2-7.[263] 8 Bit Arcade released an 8-bit chiptune rendition titled "Time Machine (8-Bit Computer Game Version)" on their 2019 album The Ultimate Black Sabbath (8-Bit Computer Game Versions).[264]
ArtistRelease TitleYearNotes
PegazusBreaking the Chains2008Bonus track
Circle of SilenceA Light in the Black: A Tribute to Ronnie James Dio2015Tribute compilation
8 Bit ArcadeThe Ultimate Black Sabbath (8-Bit Computer Game Versions)2019Chiptune version

Tomorrow's Dream

"Tomorrow's Dream", the second track on Black Sabbath's 1972 album Vol. 4, has been covered by various heavy metal and alternative rock artists, often preserving its heavy riff-driven structure while adapting it to different styles such as doom metal and grunge.[265] Notable studio covers include:
  • Eld in 1990, an early adaptation by the Norwegian heavy metal band.[265]
  • Screaming Trees in 1992, featured as a b-side on their "Dollar Bill" single from the Sweet Oblivion era, infusing the track with grunge elements.[265][266]
  • Wallside on June 14, 1997.[265]
  • Pentagram on October 30, 2015, appearing on the tribute compilation Sweet Leaf: A Stoner Rock Salute to Black Sabbath, where the doom pioneers delivered a sludge-heavy rendition.[265][267]
  • Faustian Slip on July 14, 2017.[265]
  • Party Gator on February 4, 2018.[265]
  • Leonids on August 31, 2019.[265]
  • The Obsessed in 2020, included on the tribute album Black Sabbath Vol. 4 [Redux] released by Magnetic Eye Records, emphasizing the song's doom roots with Scott "Wino" Weinrich's vocals.[265][268]
Sheavy also recorded a version in 1996 on their album Soma Storic, maintaining a stoner rock fidelity to the original.[269] Live performances, such as Van Halen's 1976 rendition during an opening slot for Black Sabbath, exist in bootleg recordings but lack official releases.[270]

TV Crimes

Plan 4, an Argentine heavy metal band, covered "TV Crimes" as track 3 on the tribute compilation Sabbath Crosses: Tributo a Black Sabbath, released July 30, 2004, by Blackstar Records.[271][272] The album features 13 tracks by South American acts, including Nativo's rendition of "War Pigs" and Barilari's take on "Heaven and Hell", produced as a homage to Black Sabbath's discography.[273] Independent covers include a 2014 performance by American metal band Nukem, recorded as a demo and uploaded to YouTube, emphasizing tributes to Ronnie James Dio's vocals.[274] Around 2010, the band Lord Divine released a cover via YouTube, maintaining the original's aggressive riffing and structure.[275] In 2021, a collaborative cover featuring bassist Felipe Andreoli was shared online, blending multiple musicians' interpretations.[276]
ArtistYearReleaseNotes
Plan 42004Sabbath Crosses: Tributo a Black SabbathTribute album track; Argentine production.[272]
Nukem2014YouTube demoFan-recorded; highlights Dio influence. [274]
Lord Divine2010YouTubeObscure band cover preserving original tempo.[275]

Under the Sun/Every Day Comes and Goes

Soulfly recorded a cover of "Under the Sun" for the tribute compilation Nativity in Black II: A Tribute to Black Sabbath, released in 2000.[277] This version appears as a bonus track on the European edition of their album 3 in 2002.[278] Bongzilla included a stoner metal rendition on their debut album Stash, originally released in 1999.[279] Zakk Sabbath, a Black Sabbath tribute project led by guitarist Zakk Wylde, featured the song on the compilation Vol. 4 [Redux], released on October 30, 2020.[280] Sanctorum performed a medley version as part of a Black Sabbath tribute on the compilation Hell Rules 2, released in 2000.[281] Other recorded covers include those by Korzus (1989), Entombed (1997), Thoughts of Ionesco (1998), One Inch Giant (2012, medley), and Stalwart (2012).[282] Gojira has performed live covers multiple times in 2025, including at the "Back to the Beginning" event honoring Ozzy Osbourne on July 5 in Birmingham, UK.[93]

War Pigs

Cake recorded a studio version of "War Pigs" for their 2007 compilation album B-Sides and Rarities, featuring their signature minimalist arrangement with trumpet accents.[283][284] Faith No More performed "War Pigs" extensively in live sets throughout the late 1980s and 1990s, including a 1990 concert appearance joined by Ozzy Osbourne on vocals and James Hetfield on guitar.[285] A live recording from their 1990 Brixton Academy show was later included on tribute compilations.[286] T-Pain released a studio cover in 2023 as part of his live album On Top of the Covers (Live from The Sun Rose), blending auto-tune effects with the original's heavy riff; Osbourne publicly endorsed it as "the best cover of 'War Pigs' ever."[287][288] Judas Priest debuted a live cover of "War Pigs" on July 2, 2025, during a concert as a tribute to Black Sabbath and Osbourne, later issuing a charity studio version featuring Osbourne's vocals on September 25, 2025, with proceeds supporting medical research.[289][290][291] Other notable renditions include Tesla's appearance on the 1994 tribute album Nativity in Black, emphasizing hard rock fidelity to the original, and Dream Theater's progressive metal interpretation in live sets.[292]

Wheels of Confusion/The Straightener

Rondellus covered "Wheels of Confusion/The Straightener" on their 2003 album Sabbatum: A Medieval Tribute to Black Sabbath, reinterpreting the track with medieval instruments and Latin lyrics sung by female voices accompanied by a frame drum.[293][294] Cathedral recorded a version for the 1994 tribute album Masters of Misery: Black Sabbath â€“ The Earache Tribute, released by Earache Records, preserving the doom metal style of the original.[54][295] Thou released a sludge metal rendition in 2020 as part of the tribute compilation Vol. 4 (A Tribute to Black Sabbath), emphasizing the song's heavy riffing and atmospheric elements.[296] Viscera/// offered an independent cover on February 11, 2013, available via Bandcamp, maintaining fidelity to the original's structure.[297]

When Death Calls

Swedish epic doom metal band Sorcerer released a cover of "When Death Calls" as a digital single on October 8, 2021, via Metal Blade Records.[298][299] The track, originating from Black Sabbath's 1989 album Headless Cross, was recorded as a tribute to the Tony Martin-era Sabbath material, with Sorcerer citing it as one of the band's strongest doomy compositions.[298] A music video accompanying the release features the band's performance, emphasizing the song's heavy riffing and atmospheric elements.[300][301] The cover maintains the original's structure while adapting it to Sorcerer's style, clocking in at approximately 6:56 in length.[302] No other professionally released covers by notable artists have been documented.[299]

Who are You

"Who Are You?", the sixth track on Black Sabbath's 1973 album Sabbath Bloody Sabbath, has been covered by multiple bands, often preserving its ominous, psychedelic tone inspired by George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four.[303]
ArtistYearRelease
New Clear Family1990New Clear Family
O.L.D.1992Lo Flux Tube
Society I1999Hidden in Plain View
Goatsnake2004Trampled Spirit (compilation)
O.L.D.'s rendition, featuring grindcore elements, appeared on the 1992 tribute album Eternal Masters but originated on their debut full-length.[305] Goatsnake's version emphasizes doom metal heaviness in a split release with Thorr's Hammer.[306] Less documented covers include those by Catapult The Sun on their 2010s EP Cathode and Oathblade as an independent metal track.[307][308]

Wicked World

Spirit Caravan, a doom and stoner metal band, released a cover of "Wicked World" on October 22, 2002.[309] Skinless, known for their brutal death metal style, included a version on their album Trample the Weak, Hurdle the Dead, released June 13, 2006.[310] Through the Stone recorded their rendition on June 5, 2012.[309] The Casualties of Jazz produced an instrumental cover in 2004.[309] Zakk Sabbath, the Black Sabbath tribute project led by guitarist Zakk Wylde, released a studio version on September 4, 2020, and has performed it live on multiple occasions, including in 2023 and 2025.[309] [311] Caustic Casanova issued their cover on October 30, 2020.[309] Thrash metal band Slayer performed a live cover during their set at the "Back to the Beginning" event in Birmingham on July 5, 2025, as part of a Black Sabbath tribute.[312] Metal Allegiance, a supergroup featuring members from various metal acts, played the song live at the House of Blues in Anaheim on January 24, 2019, with vocalist Bobby "Blitz" Ellsworth of Overkill.[313]

Zero the Hero

"Zero the Hero" was written by Ian Gillan, Tony Iommi, Geezer Butler, and Bill Ward for Black Sabbath's 1983 album Born Again.[314] The track, known for its heavy riffing and dark lyrical themes, has inspired several covers, primarily within metal subgenres like death and industrial metal.[314]
ArtistYearReleaseNotes
Cannibal Corpse1993Hammer Smashed Face EPDeath metal rendition featuring aggressive vocals and faster tempo.
Godflesh1997Masters of Misery: The Earache Tribute to Black SabbathIndustrial metal version emphasizing grinding guitars and electronic elements.[315]
Black Symphony2001Tears of BloodPower metal cover on track 15, maintaining the original's structure with symphonic additions.[316]
Thunderhead2024Were You Told the Truth About Hell?Hard rock/metal take released with an official video.[317]
Lesser-known covers include Sauron (Argentine band) in 2004 and teh end in 2023, though details on official releases remain limited.[314] These interpretations highlight the song's enduring appeal in heavy music circles, often preserving its doomy atmosphere while adapting to performers' styles.[314]

Junior's Eyes

"Junior's Eyes", from Black Sabbath's 1978 album Never Say Die!, has been covered by a few artists, primarily in studio and live formats.[318] Black Label Society recorded a studio version, released on August 11, 2010, as part of their album Order of the Black.[319][320] Rondellus, an Estonian medieval ensemble, included a Latin-language adaptation titled "Oculi Filioli" on their 2003 tribute album Sabbatum: A Medieval Tribute to Black Sabbath, performed on period instruments.[321] Black Mountain released a studio cover in 2019, drawing from Sabbath's heavy psych influences.[322] Guns N' Roses performed a live rendition on July 5, 2025, during the "Back to the Beginning" event at Villa Park in Birmingham, England, as part of a Sabbath tribute set; they reprised it later that month in Warsaw, Poland.[93][323]
